p: Northern peatlands are important for global carbon storage, holding ~30% of global soil carbon [ 1]. Peatlands develop under cool temperatures and high moisture and thus are tightly regulated by climate [ 2], [ 3]. Peatlands accumulate carbon when net primary productivity exceeds decomposition, with decomposition limited by both the waterlogged conditions that characterize peatlands [ 4], [ 5] and the decay resistance of Sphagnum species, which dominate many northern peatlands. This recalcitrant nature of Sphagnum tissue is attributed to the inhibitive effects of its litter chemistry on microbial decomposition [ 6â€“ 8]. Sphagnum species contribute up to 50% of organic soil carbon in many northern peatlands [ 4].
